channel.title: ðŸ“š Network Protocols on Analyst
channel.description: Recent content in ðŸ“š Network Protocols on Analyst

item.title: ðŸ“š General Network Terminology
item.description: Network Topology It’s a geometric arrangment of hosts and network devices. Can be physical (cables and PCs' layout) or logical (informaiton transmission methods).

item.title: ðŸ“š TCP/IP Stack Overview
item.description: This article is an overview of TCP/IP protocol stack. I will cover in detail what happens when a request to, say, bakerst221b.

item.title: ðŸ“š Physical Layer
item.description: This article is about some general stuff that happens on the physical layer. CSMA/CD =

item.title: ðŸ“š Data Link Layer
item.description: This is a protocol of TCP/IP suite, Data Link Layer. The first layer after physical layer is a data link layer and the protocol in use here is Ethernet II.

item.title: ðŸ“š Network Layer Description
item.description: Network Address Translation - mostly to map local IPs to public ones, but sometimes used to map between two public or local networks.

item.title: ðŸ“š Wireless
item.description: Attacks iwconfig airmon-ng check kill airmon-ng start wlan0 iwconfig airodump-ng wlan0mon airdump-ng -c <channel number> --bssid <access point MAC> -w capture wlan0mon to capture the handshake or enough data to deduce the key.

item.title: ðŸ“š DHCP
item.description: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol. Listening on 67 port. Sending from 68. DHCP Discover (Broadcast) C-> S

item.title: ðŸ“š DNS
item.description: Domain Name System. Translates IPs to domain names like 192.168.1.1 to router.lan and visa versa.

item.title: ðŸ“š IRC
item.description: IRC stands for Internet Relay Chat. Used for instant messaging. Usually sits at port 6667. On Linux can be installed and run with sudo invoke-rc.

item.title: ðŸ“š Kerberos
item.description: Structure The Flow - Wanna talk - Ok. Let’s talk. Here is my public key. Here are the protocols that I support.

item.title: ðŸ“š SMB
item.description: Over TCP - 445 port Over NetBIOS API UDP - ports 137, 138 TCP - ports 137, 139 NBF (legacy) Powershell command + win reg for SMB 1,2,3.

item.title: ðŸ“š SSH
item.description: Intro Secure shell. Common ports: 22. Structure ![photo_2021-02-16 11.58.08](images/photo_2021-02-16 11.58.08.jpeg) The Flow - Wanna talk

item.title: ðŸ“š Syslog
item.description: Not sure yet wether it belongs to this section. It makes the most sense to put it here until I am sure.

item.title: ðŸ“š SSL and TLS
item.description: This article explains how SSL and its successsor work. Intro SSL makes use of assymmetric encryption for verification and symmetric encryption for data exchanging.

item.title: ðŸ“š ARP
item.description: This article is about ARP protocol. It’s used to map IP addresses to physical (MAC) addresses.

item.title: ðŸ“š ICMP
item.description: ICMP protocol is needed for troubleshooting. For an TCP/IP stack here is what ICMP request looks like in a frame:

item.title: ðŸ“š IP
item.description: This article is about IP protocol (v4, v6 and IPX). IPv4 Number on top and along the left edge are bits (not bytes).

item.title: ðŸ“š TCP
item.description: This article collects the basics of TCP protocol. Its friend UDP (transport layer protocol as well) is faster but less reliable.
